title: How do we find the equation of a circle given four points on its circumference? - Quora

response.answer_text: The equation of a circle given three points on its circumference Let the three points be P₀:(x₀,y₀), P₁:(x₁,y₁) and P₂:(x₂,y₂).The equation of the perpendicular bisector of (x₀,y₀) and (x₁,y₁) is 2(x₁–x₀)x + 2(y₁–y₀)y = x₁²–x₀²+y₁²–y₀². Let a=2(x₁–x₀), b=2(y₁–y₀), c=x₁²–x₀²+y₁²–y₀².The equation of the perpendicular bisector of (x₀,y₀) and (x₂,y₂) is 2(x₂–x₀)x + 2(y₂–y₀)y = x₂²–x₀²+y₂²–y₀². Let d=2(x₂–x₀), e=2(y₂–y₀), f= x₂²–x₀²+y₂²–y₀².The intersection of these lines is the centre of the circle is ((c×e–b×f)/(a×e–b×d), (a×f–c×d)/(a×e–b×d)). Let x₃=(c×e–b×f)/(a×e–b×d), y₃=(a×f–c×d)/(a×e–b×d)The circle is then: (x – x₃)² + (y – y₃)² = (x₀ – x₃)² + (y₀ – y₃)²  or Let the three points be P₀:(x₀,y₀), P₁:(x₁,y₁) and P₂:(x₂,y₂).The equation of the line perpendicular to the line segment P₀P₁ and passing through P₁ is (x₁–x₀)x+(y₁–y₀)y=(x₁–x₀)x₁+(y₁–y₀)y₁Let a=x₁–x₀, b=y₁–y₀, c=(x₁–x₀)x₁+(y₁–y₀)y₁.The equation of the line perpendicular to the line segment P₀P₂ and passing through P₂ is (x₂–x₀)x+(y₂–y₀)y=(x₂–x₀)x₂+(y₂–y₀)y₂Let d=x₂-x₀, e=y₂-y₀, f=x₂²–x₀²+y₂²–y₀².The intersection of these lines is P₃:((c×e–b×f)/(a×e–b×d), (a×f–c×d)/(a×e–b×d)). P₀P₃ is a diameter of the circle, so an equation of the circle is then (x–x₀)(x–x₃) + (y–y₀)(y–y₃) = 0In a more familiar form, the circle is then: (x – ½(x₀+x₃))² + (y – ½(y₀+y₃))² = ¼((x₀–x₃)² + (y₀–y₃)²)
